Topic.Title: Is this true or a pump

Message.Msg: Someone that truly gets it. Everyone has assumed AMZN is always the tougher/better competitor and only the others get hurt. The method through which AMZN has done this has been to rely upon a tax subsidy ranging from 5-10% and aggressively pricing product to knock out weak retailers who have large fixed cost who couldn't match AMZN's effective tax subsidized price. First, that is changing. And it will be material, particularly on higher priced consumer electronics products. Anyone who says otherwise if full of crap. Second, AMZN's competition for digital music and books, going forward, will be Apple and Google. For those who missed it, Apple basically said to the DOJ "We're not settling. You did this all at the bidding of AMZN, holding 20+ off the record meeting with AMZN employees at AMZN HQ and it further cements AMZN's monopoly position. We're going to trial". Apple has plenty of money to go to trial and I suspect AMZN will take a brand hit on this one. Having said that, if Apple loses, I expect some scorched earth. Apple and Google could (in order to "promote tablets" price iBooks/GoogleBooks at 10% BELOW Amazon. Neither makes their money there and the "marketing cost" might amount to a few hundred million. But, the impact to Amazon would be devastating, losing its core source of monopolistid cash that it uses to attack others... The point is simple. Apple and Google have so much cash and make so much cash that they can LOSE CASH going after AMZN's crown jewel (and the DOJ would have NO GROUNDS for complaint since the current complaint is that Apple colluded to raise price to consumers). Would it move the needle for Apple? NO. Would it materially hurt Google? NO. Would it make AMZN vulnerable? Yes. Third, Rackspace OpenStack, HP Cloud and Google Cloud Platform are going to slowly erode AWS growth, margins and profitability. A few articles: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenStack -- OpenStack is open source infrastrucure as a service project, started by NASA and RackSpace to overcome proprietary/lock-in effects. Has big momentum behind it to wipe away Amazon's lead. HP Cloud and Rackspace OpenStack offerings are just the beginning. http://www.rackspace.com/cloud/public/servers/compare/ -- Rackspace's propaganda showing its comparison to AWS. HP Cloud is matching AWS pricing everywhere AND providing higher service levels for free. HP has definitely been moving more in this direction, so it will be interesting to see if a desperate dying company still with vast financial resources and technological capability can compete here. My gut says this will be part of HP's comeback story, since HP NEEDS to get traction in a secular growth area. Fourth, eBay has got its mojo back and it going to be giving AMZN a better run for the money in the core (ESPECIALLY if MSFA doesn't pass and eBay's merchants don't have to collect tax while AMZN does...). All the analysts beat up Google for fighting too many fronts. The reality is that Google has a cash machine and $50B hoard. It could go years without revenue... Amazon has sprawled just as much, but has neither the cash hoard nor the cash flow to sustain aggressive responses from competitors in each segment. Amazon is WAY more vulnerable than anyone is making it out to be. Might AMZN overcome and grow into this valuation. It's possible. But, the odds are WAY higher that, aided by recession in 2013 (and just so we are clear, the US would already be in recession if the deficit wasn't 10% of GDP. Take it to 5% and we're negative folks...All the financial pundits conveniently ignore that) retail sales contract and price competition gets more aggressive in each business Amazon is in. Shorts, be patient. Don't buy ST puts. Don't buy what you cannot maintain for a year. If you aren't greedy, you'll do well.

Message.Title: valuation
Message.Msg: I'm new to AMZN and short. If you think the company can triple the annualized EBITDA from last quarter over the next five years, assume a terminal value of 10x on the 5th year EBITDA (that has now tripled to $7.5B) and would be willing to take a 15% annual return if you purchased the company today, you would pay $111 per share. Ooops, I forgot to deduct the $2.4B in debt and the $4.3B in operating lease obligations that would have to be paid off at sale. So, after creditor claims, the stock would be worth $95 per share. What's on the near term (next 5 years) horizon that will propel AMZN's EBITDA to a 35% compounded annual growth rate just to get the share value to $95? What is the share value doing at $241 currently?
